1.title: Gone Girl - Don't Underestimate the Screenwriter
1.plot: Gone Girl uses classic screenwriting techniques to tell its twisty, modern noir story. This video examines three of the techniques used by screenwriter Gillian Flynn to see how and why they work so well.

2.title: Independence Day - What Makes it So Great
2.plot: Most disaster movies are comprised of boring characters, uninteresting antagonists, and a ton of so-what deus-ex-machina action scenes. Independence Day manages to avoid these pitfalls and succeeds where most movies fall short, making it a memorable and exciting film 20 years after its release.

3.title: How Ghostbusters Became Ghostbusters
3.plot: The screenplay for Ghostbusters is actually pretty underwhelming if you only focus on the details. But if you zoom out and look at the macro-scale of writing - coming up with a premise and figuring out how to execute it - Ghostbusters stands as a great example of the importance of execution. It's not just what your story is about, it's how you tell it.

4.title: American Beauty (Part 1) - The Art of Character
4.plot: American Beauty is one of my favorite films, and there are so many lessons to be learned from its fantastic screenplay. In this video, I cover how screenwriter Alan Ball designs and reveals character.

5.title: American Beauty (Part 2) - The Missing 27 Pages
5.plot: In the last week of editing, director Sam Mendes cut out a big portion of the film. Why? What are in the missing 27 pages that were cut from screenwriter Alan Ball's original version of American Beauty?

6.title: The Dark Knight - Creating the Ultimate Antagonist
6.plot: Heath Ledger's performance as The Joker is universally celebrated-and with good reason-but there is more to the character than his excellent performance. In this video I analyze what makes The Joker the perfect antagonist for The Dark Knight.

7.title: Nightcrawler - Empathy for the Antihero
7.plot: The protagonist of Nightcrawler is motivated, clever, and a sociopath - and despite him taking unforgivable actions, the audience stays engaged in the story. Why? This video analyzes how to create empathy for an antihero.

8.title: Moonrise Kingdom - Where Story Meets Style
8.plot: In Moonrise Kingdom, Wes Anderson's style is the perfect match for the story. He uses details to create a believable world, establishes the rules of this fantastical story, and creates a tone that forms a connection between the audience and the characters of Suzy and Sam.

9.title: The Shining - Quietly Going Insane Together
9.plot: The Shining, more than any other horror film, frightens me on a deep, psychological level. This video explores what exactly makes it so creepy.

10.title: Whiplash vs. Black Swan - The Anatomy of the Obsessed Artist
10.plot: A comparison of how the tale of the obsessed artist is told in Darren Aronofsky's "Black Swan" starring Natalie Portman, Mila Kunis, and Vincent Cassel, and Damien Chazelle's "Whiplash" starring Miles Teller and J. K. Simmons.

11.title: Ex Machina - The Control of Information
11.plot: At its most basic level, a story is simply information being communicated over time. Ex Machina is a great example of how a screenwriter's ability to carefully control a story's information can make for a compelling film.

1.title: The Social Network - Sorkin, Structure, and Collaboration
1.plot: An in-depth look at screenwriting and the art behind it.

2.title: When Harry Met Sally - Breaking Genre Conventions
2.plot: When Harry Met Sally takes the conventions of a classic from-hate-to-love story and flips them on their head, creating a unique and charming film.

3.title: Inglourious Basterds - The Elements of Suspense
3.plot: Examining the elements of suspense that Quentin Tarantino put to use in the opening scene of Inglourious Basterds.

4.title: Breaking Bad - Crafting a TV Pilot
4.plot: Breaking Bad is celebrated as one of the best TV shows of all time-but every series has to start somewhere. This video looks at how the structure of the pilot episode sets up everything the audience needs to know about the series.

5.title: Rogue One vs. The Force Awakens - The Fault in Our Star Wars
5.plot: In this video, I examine some of the flaws and imperfections in Rogue One and The Force Awakens to extract the lessons we can learn about showing vs. telling, active protagonists, and meaningful consequences.

6.title: Arrival - Examining an Adaptation
6.plot: Examining how Arrival was adapted from the short story it was based on, how clever editing kept the focus on the protagonist, and why good science fiction is really a study of humanity.

7.title: True Detective vs. Se7en - Creating Light Amongst The Dark
7.plot: Despite the dark and gruesome subject matters of True Detective and Se7en, the character arcs of the main characters tell a story of profound optimism.

8.title: Telling a Story from the Inside Out
8.plot: Creating a story is often as much of a journey for the writer as it is for the characters. In this video, I look at the writing process for Inside Out to examine how the powerful emotions in the film were inspired by the real-life experiences of the writers.

9.title: Game of Thrones - How to Evoke Emotion
9.plot: This video looks at how Game of Thrones-and the Battle of the Bastards episode in particular-evokes such strong emotions in its audience by making sure every scene has a compelling value transition.

10.title: Memento - Telling a Story In Reverse
10.plot: Analyzing Christopher Nolan's film Memento, and how he manages to tell a compelling story when most of it happens in reverse chronological order.

11.title: Blade Runner - Constructing a Future Noir
11.plot: Blade Runner was the first film to take the thematic elements of classic film noir and bring them into a sci-fi, dystopian future. This video analyzes those elements and examines why the private detective of classic film noir is the perfect fit for the world of Blade Runner.
